ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This course was conducted through a combination of an in-person live virtual lecture/seminar three times a week and a asynchronous class two times a week.
N/A
Asynchronous activities and work
vhl problems and independent practice

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Honestly you learn more Spanish in L1 than I expected. By the end of L1, you are able to converse with someone in Spanish and you know the present, past tense, and future progressive.

I learned so much throughout this course. I started this course having no prior knowledge of the Spanish language, and I now feel as if I can speak pretty well at a beginner level. I am excited to learn more during more advanced Spanish classes.
A good overview of basic spanish vocab (travel, cooking) and basic grammar (present, past tense, pronouns)
Reading, writing, and speaking in Spanish and learning about culture in spanish speaking countries.
I learned a lot of introductory Spanish vocabulary and grammar. Even after only one semester, I find that I can actually hold a simple conversation pretty well.
I learned basic level spanish and a solid understanding of basic grammar

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Weakness - assignments / class every day
Strength - the amount you learn in 1 semester, Pilar. Pilar was so kind and positive to work with.
I do not think there were many weaknesses throughout this course. I appreciated the concentration on a multitude of assignments, which made me less stressed out about each of them.

The course is well structured to promote learning and is very interactive.

A huge issue of the course is the inherent disparity between students of different backgrounds. Unfortunately, it will be incredibly difficult for students coming in without any spanish background, which is obviously troubling for an introductory course. The course needs to think more about grading on improvement that simply raw ability to speak and write, because it is clearly unfair in this regard.

Strengths are opportunities for class participation and interaction, clarity, and speed.

Weaknesses were just the deficits of online learning, but I enjoyed it nonetheless.

I really enjoyed this course. Obviously considering the pandemic, conversation and practicing speaking through Zoom was not ideal, but in our class we still found a way to talk a lot and engage with each other. My only grievance with the course is that sometimes the homework assignments were really repetitive, but I understand that repetition is a necessary part of learning a new language. Maybe once in a while as a treat we could have a shorter homework day or a day without Supersite homework or something. Overall, though, I really don't have any complaints about this course. Muy divertido!
very passionate teacher and engaging class activities, it was unfortunate that the class was on zoom but the teacher kept the class engaged

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lots of partner video recordings forced you to get to know others in the class
I would have liked to have taken this class in person and immersed myself more with the language, but given the circumstances, I think that this class allowed for virtual engagement.
The online format was good, and reliance on the Supersite was a good idea
Virtual games to practice spanish, websites to help us practice on our own, asynchronous days to give us a break from the screen

In our Zoom sessions, our profesora made sure that everyone would have enough speaking time, and while a lot of the engagement was one at a time and less conversational, I still felt like we were learning at a very quick pace and were picking up conversational skills. We had breakout rooms in which we'd speak in Spanish with one or two other students, which was an effective way to practice some of the grammatical rules. We also did asynchronous days on Tuesdays and Thursdays, which I liked a lot. We would have some extra homework on those days, and while conversation is very important for absorbing a new language, having those days to study on our own was very effective for me.
course practices were well designed to keep class engaged

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, esp with Pilar. She is such a nice person!
Yes! I would definitely recommend this course for people interested in learning Spanish if they had not had any prior exposure to the language.
If you don't come from a spanish background, you will likely struggle.
I would - it was a great introductory course for spanish and I have a good foundation to become more fluent.

I would. Not only is the material interesting and very useful, but the class itself is also a lot of fun. You get to know the group of people pretty well, and profesora was a very nice, patient, and motivational teacher who helped us succeed. I would highly recommend this course to anyone wanting to learn Spanish, or even just to fulfill their language requirement.
yes if they want to learn basic spanish grammar and speaking
